firstChapter.htmlHeader: Breast screening: Summary
firstChapter.htmlStringContent:
• One in nine women will develop breast cancer, and it is more common in women over the age of 50 years.
  • The NHS Breast Screening Programme in England was set up in 1988, and provides 3-yearly routine breast screening to women.
    • Breast screening uses mammography radiography to detect small changes in the breast before other symptoms or signs of breast cancer.
    • Breast screening detects about 30% of breast cancers and is estimated to save 1300 lives per year in the UK.
    • If breast cancer is found at an early stage, there is an increased chance of breast-conserving surgery and a better prognosis of long-term survival.
  • Invitations for routine mammography screening are sent out to women aged 50–70 years in England, Northern Ireland, Scotland, and Wales.
    • Some women aged 47–49 years and 71–73 years in England are also invited for screening as part of an ongoing cluster-randomized trial of extending the breast screening age-range.
    • Women aged over 70 years are invited to make their own appointments every 3 years.
    • Women at increased risk of breast cancer (for example with a strong family history) may be eligible for breast screening before 50 years of age.
  • Women should be supported to make an informed decision about participation in the breast screening programme, and should be informed about:
    • How breast screening is organized.
    • Where the mammogram is likely to be done.
    • Preparing for the mammogram.
    • What to expect at and after their appointment.
  • Benefits of breast screening include:
    • Reduction in mortality.
    • More breast-conserving treatment due to an increase in early detection of breast cancer.
  • Harms of breast screening include:
    • Over-diagnosis leading to unnecessary treatment.
    • False-positive mammograms, leading to unnecessary further investigations.
    • False reassurance, due to missed cancer and incorrect diagnosis.
    • Pain and discomfort, due to mammography.
    • Psychological distress, such as anxiety or uncertainty, for example following a false-positive result.
    • Radiation exposure, which may increase the risk of breast cancer.
  • Women with breast implants should be informed that some of the breast tissue in women with implants is obscured by the radiopaque implant during routine mammography.
    • Additional screening images may be taken at the initial mammography appointment, to visualise as much breast tissue as possible to improve cancer detection rates.
  • Women with a physical disability that may make breast screening difficult should:
    • Be advised to contact the local breast screening service to get advice on whether mammography is technically possible, and where the best place would be to attend.
  • Women with a learning disability or who lack mental capacity to make an informed decision about breast screening should:
    • Be assessed for whether she has fluctuating mental capacity, in which case, the decision about participating in screening should be delayed until the woman is able to decide for herself.
    • Have a best interests decision made on her behalf if she has ongoing lack of mental capacity to make an informed decision.
